questions.text: According to the Hindu Marriage Act, of 1955, which of the following is considered a ground for a void marriage?
questions.explanation:
Void Marriage

Voidable Marriage

Null from the time of inception.

Remains valid until annulled by the court

Bigamy (entering into another marriage without dissolution of the first).

Impotence (Option A ruled out)

Prohibited degree of relationship (blood relations), unless permitted by custom.

Unsoundness of mind of either party at the time of marriage (Option C ruled out)

Sapinda relationship (relationship extending to 3rd generation in the line of ascent through the mother and 5th generation through the father)

Consent obtained by force, fraud, or misconception of facts (Option D ruled out)
 

Pregnancy of the woman by another person, unknown to the husband at the time of marriage

questions.text: Which of the following is not considered a ground for divorce under the Hindu Marriage Act, of 1955?

A 30-year-old woman comes to the clinic with her newborn baby. She explains that her husband passed away six months ago, shortly after she became pregnant. The baby was born healthy, and she is excited to introduce him to the world. What type of child is this?

A 32-year-old woman arrives at the hospital in labour. During delivery, it is noted that one of her twins is white, while the other is black whereas both the parents are of Caucasian descent. The mother recalls having had intercourse with two different partners within a short timeframe during her ovulation. What phenomenon best explains this situation?
questions.explanation:
Superfecundation

Superfetation

(Option A ruled out)
  • This refers to the fertilization of two ova released from the ovary during the same ovulation cycle, occurring through two separate acts of intercourse at short intervals.
  • The term also describes cases where two different males father fraternal twins, known as heteropaternal superfecundation. This can result in twins who are half-siblings, exemplified by one baby being white and the other black.
  • Medico-legal Aspect: Significant differences in the appearance of the two babies may lead to suspicions of adultery or infidelity.
  • This occurs when two ova are fertilized at different times during the ovulation cycle, specifically involving the fertilization of a second ovum in a pregnant woman.
  • In this case, one fetus tends to be more developed than the other. They may be born simultaneously, showing different levels of maturation, or at different times, which can range from 1 to 3 months apart.
  • The likelihood of superfetation is higher in women with a septate or double uterus.

questions.text: A 32 y/o woman and her partner are having difficulty conceiving due to poor sperm motility. The doctor recommends artificial insemination. Which of the following methods would likely offer the highest success rate for this couple?
questions.explanation:
Artificial Insemination Methods

Type

Method

Advantages

Limitations

IUI (Intrauterine Insemination) (Option B)

Sperm is injected into the uterus.

High success, minimal pain

-

ICI (Intracervical Insemination) (Option A ruled out)

Semen is placed in the cervix, which then travels to the uterus and fallopian tubes on its own.

Low cost, suitable for various couples

Lower success rate

 

Not available option for women with thick cervical mucous.

IUTPI (Intrauterine Tuboperitoneal Insemination) (Option D ruled out)

Sperm injected into Fallopian tubes

Bypasses infertility issues

-

Intratubal Insemination (Option C ruled out)

In this procedure, a catheter goes through the cervix and uterus and sperm is injected only into the Fallopian tubes

Effective for cervical mucus issues

More invasive

questions.text: A couple is considering artificial insemination with donor sperm (AID). What legal issue is most likely to arise if the procedure is performed without the husband's consent?

options.label: D
options.text: Increased risk of psychological issues in the child

questions.text: Which term refers to the inability to initiate or maintain the sexual arousal pattern in females or an incapacity to achieve orgasm?
What is the expected result of a Lateral Traction Test in an individual who is not accustomed to anal penetration?

options.label: A
options.text: Relaxation and dilation of the anal sphincter up to 4-5 cm

options.label: B
options.text: Reflex constriction of the anal sphincter

options.label: C
options.text: No response in the anal sphincter

questions.correct_answer: B. Reflex constriction of the anal sphincter

questions.text: Which of the following statements best describes the role of the Sexual Assault Forensic Examination (rape kit) concerning victim care?

options.label: A
options.text: The examination focuses solely on collecting evidence and does not provide medical treatment.

options.label: B
options.text: The examination can help victims access immediate medical care and provide resources for their health needs.

options.label: C
options.text: The examination requires all victims to file a police report and then provides resources for their health needs.

options.label: D
options.text: The examination is primarily for legal purposes and does not address the psychological well-being of the victim.

questions.correct_answer: B. The examination can help victims access immediate medical care and provide resources for their health needs.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female presents to a clinic with a sore throat and discomfort following a recent sexual encounter. During the examination, the clinician notes abrasions on her mouth and lips. Which sexual act is most likely associated with the injuries observed in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Unnatural sexual Acts

Sodomy

(Option A ruled out)
  • Definition: Anal intercourse, historically associated with the town of Sodom.
  • Parties Involved: This can occur between males or between a male and female.
  • Legal Aspects: Consensual sodomy is not punishable; non-consensual acts lead to punishment for the active agent.
  • Contexts: Common in confined environments (e.g., prisons, barracks) where individuals are isolated for long periods.
  • Evidence: Physical examination may show signs like abrasions or relaxed anal muscles in habitual cases.

Sin of Gomorrah (Buccal Coitus)

(Option B)
  • Definition: Oral sexual act involving a male organ in another’s mouth.
  • Historical Context: Referred to as a "sin" in the town of Gomorrah.
  • Legal Aspects: Punishable when performed without consent.
  • Physical Evidence: Possible abrasions or teeth marks on the penis; semen in the victim's mouth may be detected up to nine hours after the act.
  • Risks: Potential for accidental death if the penis blocks the airway.

Bestiality

(Option D ruled out)
  • Definition: Sexual acts between humans and animals, typically involving smaller animals or pets.
  • Common Animals: Includes livestock (e.g., calves, sheep) and household pets (e.g., dogs, cats).
  • Physical Evidence: Animal hair or secretions on the person, and human sperm or injuries in the animal’s genital area.
  • Associated Beliefs: Sometimes linked to superstitions, like the idea of curing certain diseases through intercourse with animals.

Tribadism (Female Homosexuality)

(Option C ruled out)
  • Definition: Sexual activity between women for mutual gratification, also known as lesbianism.
  • Common Acts: Includes kissing, body contact, genital apposition, and use of objects for stimulation.
  • Historical Context: Linked to the Isle of Lesbos and sometimes called “Sapphism.”
  • Social Dynamics: This can lead to intense emotional connections, and historically noted cases include jealousy and possessiveness among partners.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy exhibits extreme jealousy toward his mother’s close relationship with her new partner, showing signs of distress when she pays attention to anyone else. What psychological complex might this behaviour suggest?
questions.explanation:
Oedipus Complex

Electra Complex

Pharaoh Complex

Refers to a son’s sexual desire for his mother.

Refers to a daughter’s sexual desire for her father. (Option B ruled out)

Refers to a brother’s sexual desire for his sister. (Option A ruled out)

questions.text: Which of the following methods of violence is most likely to directly injure the uterus and cause membrane rupture?

options.label: A
options.text: Inserting foreign objects like knitting needles

options.label: D
options.text: Injecting fluids into the uterus with a syringe

questions.correct_answer: A. Inserting foreign objects like knitting needles
questions.explanation:
Methods of Violence in Criminal Abortion

General Violence

Local Violence
  • Abdominal Pressure: Applying force to the abdomen (kicking, kneeling, tight bandages, etc.) aiming to cause injury.
  • Strenuous Activities: Engaging in extreme physical activities like horse riding, jumping, or falling to induce trauma. (Option B ruled out)
  • Cupping: Using heated cups on the abdomen to create suction, possibly separating the placenta.
  • Temperature Extremes: Alternating between hot and cold baths, aiming to shock the system.
  • Syringing: Injecting harmful fluids (like soap or chemicals) into the uterus, risking infection and air embolism. (Option D ruled out)
  • Syringe Aspiration: Inserting a syringe into the cervix to aspirate the gestational sac, leading to aspiration and expulsion of contents.
  • Membrane Rupture: Using sharp objects (knitting needles, pencils) to puncture the amniotic sac, risking haemorrhage and infection. (Option A)
  • Abortion Stick: Inserting sticks soaked in irritants (like calotropis) to cause uterine contractions.
  • Cervical Dilation: Forcing open the cervix with objects to cause contractions.
  • Air Insufflation: Pumping air into the uterus to detach the foetus, risking air embolism.
  • Electric Current: Using electrical current on the cervix to induce contractions content expulsion.
  • Toxic Pastes: Injecting harmful pastes into the uterus, leads to tissue damage like necrosis and infection. (Option C ruled out)

Causes of Death in Criminal Abortion

Immediate

Delayed
  • Vagal Inhibition
  • Air Embolism
  • Fat Embolism
  • Haemorrhage
  • Amniotic Fluid Embolism
  • Septicaemia
  • Generalised Peritonitis
  • Tetanus
  • Local infection
  • Toxemia
  • Pyaemia

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is known for being an emmenagogue used in criminal abortions?
questions.explanation:
Abortifacient Drugs

Description

Abortifacient drugs are substances used in illegal abortions, posing severe health risks to women and potentially leading to death. Dosages and administration are often handled by unqualified individuals, increasing complications.

Mechanisms of Action

Ecbolics

Stimulate uterine contractions to expel the fetus.

Examples: Ergot, Hydrastis canadensis, quinine, lead, pituitary extract - oxytocin, synthetic estrogens. (Option A and B ruled out)

Emmenagogues

(Option B)

Increase menstrual flow, potentially causing abortion in high doses.

Examples: Savin, borax, apiol, rue.

Irritants

Cause reflex uterine contractions through gastrointestinal or genitourinary irritation.

  • GIT Irritants: Strong laxatives like calomel, castor oil and saline cathartics.
  • Genitourinary Irritants: Oils like pennyroyal, tansy and potassium permanganate, which can cause severe damage.

Systemic Poisoning

Induces abortion through toxic effects on the body.

Examples: Lead, copper, iron, and certain organic irritants like cantharides, and unripe papaya. (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: Which section of the BNS involves life imprisonment for causing a miscarriage without the woman’s consent?
questions.explanation:
Criminal Abortion - Legal Aspects

BNS

(Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita, 2023)

IPC Section

(Indian Penal Code, 1860)

Definition

88

(Option A ruled out)

312

Voluntary criminal abortion by anyone, including the pregnant woman, can lead to up to 3 years imprisonment and/or fine.

If the woman is "quick with child" (fetal movement felt), the punishment can extend up to 7 years and a fine.

89

(Option B)

313

Causing a miscarriage without the woman’s consent is punishable by life imprisonment or up to 10 years in prison, with a fine.

90

(Option C ruled out)

314

If a miscarriage attempt leads to the woman’s death, the responsible person faces up to 10 years in prison and a fine.

If done without her consent, the punishment can be life imprisonment or up to 10 years.

91

(Option D ruled out)

315

Actions to prevent a child from being born alive or causing death after birth can result in up to 10 years imprisonment, fine, or both.

92

316

Causing the death of a "quick unborn child" (after fetal movement) is considered culpable homicide, punishable by up to 10 years imprisonment and a fine.

questions.text: Which of the following is an indication for pregnancy termination under the eugenic grounds of the MTP Act?
questions.explanation:
Indications for MTP

Therapeutic

(Options A and B ruled out)

Pregnancy that endangers the woman's life or may cause severe physical/mental injury (e.g., cardiac disease, hypertension, epilepsy, intractable hyperemesis gravidarum, breast/ cervical cancer).

Eugenic

(Option C)

Risk of serious physical or mental abnormalities in the fetus (e.g., exposure to teratogenic drugs, infections like rubella, structural abnormalities like anencephaly).

Socio-economic

Unplanned pregnancies in low socio-economic conditions or failure of contraception.

Humanitarian

(Option D ruled out)

Pregnancy resulting from rape.

questions.text: Which of the following is classified as an induced abortion performed to protect the mother's life?
questions.explanation:
Abortion

Medical Definition

Abortion is the expulsion of an embryo or fetus weighing 500g or less, which is not capable of surviving independently. This typically corresponds to 22 weeks of gestation.

Legal Definition

Abortion is the expulsion of the products of conception from the uterus at any period before full term.

Types of Abortion

Natural/ Spontaneous Abortion

Occurs without external induction and often coincides with menstrual flow. (Option C ruled out)

It is most common in the first trimester of pregnancy.

Artificial/Induced Abortion:

Willful termination of pregnancy before fetal viability.

Legal/ Justifiable Abortion

Performed to protect the life or health of the mother and follows the MTP Act. (Option B)

Complications increase with gestational age, with higher rates in mid-trimester abortions.

Criminal/ Illegal Abortion

Induced unlawfully, often before the third month, with a high risk of complications such as infection and uterine injury. (Option A ruled out)

Complications include hemorrhagic shock, septicemia, and secondary infertility.

questions.text: A woman presents with amenorrhea, breast tenderness, and morning sickness. Which category of pregnancy signs do these symptoms belong to?
questions.explanation:
Pregnancy Signs

Presumptive Signs

(Option A)

Probable Signs

(Option B ruled out)

Positive Signs

(Option C ruled out)
  • Amenorrhea
  • Breast Changes: Tenderness, enlargement, darkened nipples, colostrum secretion.
  • Morning Sickness
  • Quickening: First fetal movements felt around 16-18 weeks.
  • Pigmentation Changes
  • Chadwick's Sign: Bluish colour of the vaginal mucosa by the 8th week.
  • Increased urination
  • Fatigue
  • Mood/Body Changes
  • Abdominal Enlargement
  • Hegar's Sign: Softening of the uterine isthmus (6-10 weeks).
  • Goodell's Sign: Softened cervix by 6th week.
  • Palmer’s Sign: Uterine contractions felt early (4-8 weeks).
  • Piskacek's Sign: Asymmetrical uterine enlargement.
  • Ballottement: Fetal rebound during an exam by 4-5 months.
  • Immunological Pregnancy Tests: Detect hCG in urine/serum.
  • Fetal Heart Sounds: Heard via stethoscope by 18-20 weeks.
  • Fetal Movements: Palpable by 20-22 weeks.
  • Ultrasound: Fetal visualisation from 4-5 weeks.
  • Radiographic Imaging: Fetal skeleton visible from 16 weeks.

questions.text: Which of the following features distinguishes a fimbriated hymen from a torn hymen due to trauma?

options.label: D
options.text: Extension of notches to the vaginal wall

questions.correct_answer: C. Mucous membrane covering intact notches
questions.explanation:
Hymen Tear

Fimbriated Hymen
  • Often, it results from sexual intercourse or trauma.
  • It can be associated with injuries to surrounding areas, such as the perineum and labia.
  • Usually occurs at the lateral edges of the labia and extends into the vaginal wall.
  • Traumatic tears may not have mucous membrane covering and can be located posteriorly. (Option B ruled out)
  • Characterised by a wavy or irregular border with symmetrical notches. (Option A ruled out)
  • Notches are typically found anteriorly and do not penetrate the vaginal wall. (Option D ruled out)
  • The mucous membrane remains intact around natural notches.
  • It requires careful examination to differentiate it from traumatic tears.

questions.text: A medical student is studying the anatomical variations of the hymen. Which of the following statements regarding hymen types and their implications is true?

options.label: A
options.text: A single central opening characterises a septate hymen.

options.label: B
options.text: The cribriform hymen features multiple small openings in the membrane.

options.label: C
options.text: An infantile hymen typically has multiple small openings.

options.label: D
options.text: The annular hymen typically have two side-by-side openings.

questions.correct_answer: B. The cribriform hymen features multiple small openings in the membrane.
questions.explanation:
Type

Description

Annular

Centrally located opening (Option D ruled out)

Semilunar

Anteriorly located opening

Infantile

Small, linear central opening (Option C ruled out)

Septate

Two side-by-side openings (Option A ruled out)

Cribriform

Multiple openings (Option B)

Vertical

Vertical orientation of the opening

Imperforate

No opening present

Cause

Description

Sexual Intercourse

The most common cause of hymen rupture.

Masturbation

The use of large objects can cause a rupture.

Accidents

Falls onto sharp objects may lead to a rupture.

Medical Procedures

Gynaecological exams or surgeries can cause a rupture.

Foreign Body Insertion

Possible in cases of abuse or forced sexual activity

Use of Sanitary Tampons

Tampon usage may contribute to hymen rupture.

questions.text: A 24 y/o woman is anxious about societal perceptions of her virginity after her first sexual experience. Which of the following statements is true regarding virginity and defloration?

options.label: A
options.text: Virginity can be medically assessed by examining the hymen.

options.label: B
options.text: Defloration is solely marked by the hymen's rupture during first intercourse.

options.label: C
options.text: Virginity is a social construct that varies across cultures.

options.label: D
options.text: False virgins always present with small and firm breasts.

questions.correct_answer: C. Virginity is a social construct that varies across cultures.
questions.explanation:
Category

True Virgin

False Virgin

Genital Signs
  • Intact, rigid, inelastic hymen; admits only a fingertip, causing pain.
  • Thick, fleshy labia majora that close the vaginal orifice; small, pink labia minora covered by labia majora.
  • Narrow vagina with prominent rugae; full finger cannot be admitted.
  • Present fossa navicularis, intact fourchette, narrow vestibule, small clitoris, intact posterior commissure.
  • Intact hymen that may be loose, elastic, or thick; admits two fingers easily.
  • Less fleshy labia majora; vaginal orifice may be visible; enlarged, pigmented labia minora.
  • Roomy vagina with less prominent rugae; full finger can be admitted.
  • Disappearance of fossa navicularis; torn and healed fourchette; wider vestibule; enlarged clitoris; possibly torn posterior commissure. (Option D ruled out)

Extra-Genital Signs

Small, hemispherical, firm breasts; pink areola.

Larger, pendulous, flabby breasts; pigmented areola.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of the Indian Council of Medical Research (ICMR) guidelines on surrogacy?

options.label: A
options.text: The surrogate mother must be under 45 years of age.

options.label: B
options.text: The ART clinic is allowed to advertise for surrogate mothers.

options.label: C
options.text: Surrogacy should only be considered for those physically or medically unable to carry a child.

options.label: D
options.text: A woman can be a surrogate mother up to three times in her lifetime.

questions.correct_answer: B. The ART clinic is allowed to advertise for surrogate mothers.
